I've found comprehensive search results comparing these three classic dystopian novels. Here's what the analysis reveals about their symbols, themes, and control mechanisms:

## Control Mechanisms Comparison

In all three books, each setting wants to strengthen the state by altering the minds of the peoples in their own way. In 1984, this means strengthening the Party, "Big Brother"; in Brave New World and Fahrenheit 451 the people are also slaves to the state.

### 1984: Control Through Fear and Surveillance
1984 explores the dystopia born of an opposite approach: the imposition of suffering and control in the name of unity and security. Orwell's portrayal of a society under the thumb of an oppressive regime exemplifies the dystopian outcome of utopian desires when implemented through the mechanisms of fear and repression.(no content)In 1984, a group called "the party" exterminates and modifies any literature or documentations of history to get society to think what the party wants them to think.

### Brave New World: Control Through Pleasure and Conditioning
In Brave New World Huxley shows that human can be tamed, and that control can be bought about through freedom rather than oppression.(no content)In the same manner, the society in Aldous Huxley's Brave New World is kept under the yoke of its leadership through perpetual drug use. Soma, a hallucinogen, takes the role of manipulating the way the society in this context perceives life.

### Fahrenheit 451: Control Through Censorship and Media
The book, Fahrenheit 451 explains how firefighters start fires rather than stopping them. A firefighter's job is do burn books, since books are illegal to have because they go against the power of technology and modernization.(no content)In Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451, the leadership has managed to draw the public from reading books. The public is therefore unable to get any other enlightenment apart from the one passed to them by the government through the media.

## Key Symbols and Themes

### Censorship and Knowledge Control
The main theme expressed in these novels is mass censorship on society. The authority figures shape society to believe what they want society to believe.(no content)As books represent knowledge in Bradbury's novel, it is clear that the act of burning books as well as the individuals who refuse to give them up represents censorship and the oppression of knowledge and freedom of speech/expression.

### Technology as Control Mechanism
The authors include ideas of fear, technology and pleasure in a way that predicts how they see today's society.(no content)Bradbury's novel, Fahrenheit 451 is not about control, but it is a novel about how television destroys curiosity in reading literature.

## Philosophical Differences in Control Methods

The comparative analysis of pleasure and pain in these novels illuminates the complexities inherent in constructing a utopian society. The excessive pleasure that characterizes Huxley's world and the restricted, punitive use of pleasure in Orwell's dystopia both reflect deviations from a balanced understanding of utopia — one that embraces rather than negates human nature.(no content)Orwell depicts how through strict measures and punishment control can be achieved, while Huxley illustrates how basic anamalistic pleasure can bend a person to someone's will.

## Common Dystopian Elements

Fahrenheit 451, 1984, and Brave New World are three different dystopias that meet their doom due to the attempted control regulations by the government using a loss of individuality, ignorance, and fear.(no content)A similarity in both dystopian societies that is shared by both texts is the theme that the ability to control the mind yields control of a society.

The search results reveal that while all three novels explore totalitarian control, they each present distinct methods: Orwell's fear-based surveillance state, Huxley's pleasure-based conditioning society, and Bradbury's media-saturated censorship regime. Together, they offer a comprehensive examination of how dystopian societies can emerge through different mechanisms of psychological and social control.
